raw_text:
Sir Paul rocks Super Bowl crowds
 
 Sir Paul McCartney wowed fans with a live mini-concert at American football's Super Bowl - and avoided any Janet Jackson-style controversies.
 
 The 62-year-old sang Hey Jude and other Beatles songs in a 12-minute set at half-time during the game in Florida. Last year, Jackson exposed a breast during a dance routine, causing outrage among millions of TV viewers and landing the CBS TV network a fine. Sir Paul, however, did nothing more racy than remove his jacket as he sang. Organisers were widely considered to be playing it safe this year by booking 62-year-old Sir Paul for his second Super Bowl show.
 
 Three years ago, he was invited to perform at the first Super Bowl after the September 11 attacks and performed his specially-written song Freedom. This time, he started off the show, at the Alltel Stadium in Jacksonville, Florida, with the Beatles numbers Drive My Car and Get Back. He then performed a mellow version of Live And Let Die, the James Bond theme he recorded with the band Wings. Finally, he closed the show with a rousing version of Hey Jude. The former Beatle resisted any temptation to refer to Janet Jackson's headline-grabbing performance last year, instead keeping banter between songs to a minimum in order to squeeze as much music as he could into his slot. The singer removed his black jacket halfway through the show - but any fans hoping for a second "Nipple-gate" were to be disappointed as he kept his red sweatshirt on underneath.
 
 Earlier, the Black Eyed Peas and Alicia Keys had provided the night's other high-profile entertainment by performing in a pre-game show. Black Eyed Peas singer Fergie was dressed in a tight orange top and purple hotpants, but nothing in her performance was likely to upset TV watchdogs. After the controversy last year - which saw CBS fined a record $550,000 (£292,000) by federal regulators - Super Bowl organisers had turned to producer Don Mischer to oversee this year's half-time show. His previous production credits included Olympic opening and closing ceremonies. The Super Bowl is watched by an audience of 144.4 million in the US, with many of the people watching are said to tune in specifically to see the entertainment put on around the event. Michael Jackson, Aerosmith, Diana Ross, Gloria Estefan and Phil Collins are among the stars who have previously graced the Super Bowl stage.
llama3.2:1b: Sir Paul McCartney performed a 12-minute live mini-concert at Super Bowl half-time during American football's game in Florida.
He sang Beatles songs including "Hey Jude" and performed three songs from his own music, "Drive My Car", "Get Back", and "Live And Let Die".
McCartney did not perform any explicit content, instead using banter between songs to fit as much music into the slot.

He was booked to avoid any incidents similar to last year's Janet Jackson performance.
The show also featured the Black Eyed Peas and Alicia Keys before McCartney's set, which included a version of Live And Let Die.

Organizers chose him as he was familiar with performing on this stage and to ensure safety for a large audience.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Sir Paul performed for the US Super Bowl in Florida this year as his second appearance, avoiding controversy by staying under tight circumference while keeping a sweatshirt.
He performed "Hey Jude" and other Beatles songs, with "Drive My Car" with The Beatles and "Live And Let Die" with Wings.
He ended midway through the show with a rousing "Hey Jude."
Previous controversies aside, the organizers relied on Don Mischer for last year's half-time performance at a major artist's event.
Earlier performers like Black Eyed Peas and Alicia Keys had their own costumes but didn't cause big trouble.
This year, Sir Paul was the longest-running performer in a Super Bowl game and drew an audience of 144 million across the country.
tinyllama:1.1b: After a first-time appearance at Super Bowl XXVIII, the legendary singer Sir Paul McCartney pulled out all stops for his second Super Bowl performance in 2014, impressing the audience with his unique brand of musical style, which included a rendition of the Beatles' classic "Drive My Car" and a live and let-die performance of the James Bond theme song "Hey Judy".
Sir Paul also performed a number of Beatles songs, including "Freeform", "Live & Let Die", and his own composition, "Get Back".
Despite facing controversy during the pre-game show last year, Sir Paul managed to avoid any headline-grabbing incidents this time around.
The event was marked by a record $550,000 fine imposed on CBS TV network for airing an explicit dance routine in their Super Bowl XXVIII halftime show.

He will avoid any controversies by removing his jacket, and fans can expect a mellow performance of their classic song "Hey Jude."
The event took place on February 7th and featured Black Eyed Peas and Alicia Keys, who performed before Fergie in a pre-game show.
The Super Bowl is typically watched by an audience of around 144 million people in the US, with many fans tuning in specifically to see the entertainment put on during the event.
